title: Britain has millions more graduates – so why has the economy got so little to show for it?
text:
One of Tony Blair’s most powerful symbolic policies was the goal of sending half of all school leavers to university.

“Education, education, education” ran his slogan, and 22 years on from his first election victory that target of university entrants was finally hit this year. Was it worth it?

Better education is supposed to be the answer to three of the biggest challenges facing the economy – weak wage growth, wheezing productivity growth and the automation of work by robots.

More years of schooling should help with all three, yet new data suggests this is not happening.

The number of graduates in the workforce is soaring, almost doubling from 6.7 million in 2004 to 12.8 million last year,...
description: One of Tony Blair’s most powerful symbolic policies was the goal of sending half of all school leavers to university.
